ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Pretty boring, Stern makes it pretty fun most of the time.

Survey course on modern Jewish philosophy. Note: this course is more intellectual history/philosophy than history, with a focus on people and ideas rather than places and dates. If Eli Stern is teaching it, definitely take it--he's really knowledgeable, will work individually on paper topics, and is easygoing about due dates. I took this course for fun, as a side academic interest, but it would probably be even more productive for religious/jewish studies majors.

The name of the course basically tells you what you're getting yourself into. The course started from Spinoza all the way to basically now. Definitely a lot of readings. And some readings, you'll enjoy more than others. And the class is super chill. The professor gives you a long period of time (longer than what you normally get in other courses) to complete two paper assignments (a midterm paper and a final paper). And he tells you exactly what you are expected to do. So you should be fine as long as you follow his directions (exactly).And yes, I would definitely recommend this class, because it is one of the best course I've taken here at yale. Though I don't think Professor Stern will be teaching next year. And in that case, I'm not sure what thisclass will be like (b/c in my opinion what basically "sells" this class is Stern's lectures).

I would recommend the course to anyone who would like to have a foundational knowledge in intellectual modern Jewish history, such as the origins of reform/conservative/orthodox, of hasidism, of different strains of zionism, and of post-Holocaust thought. Really interesting material.

I loved this course! Although it was structured as a lecture, the small enrollment enabled us to ask questions, and to some extent, have discussions. Professor Stern is an excellent lecturer and a fascinating person. His lectures connected ideas across philosophy, history, and politics for coherent explanations of complex topics. I frequently left class feeling enlightened and excited about the material. Although demanding in class, his grading is very fair.

This course is well planned and executed. It provides both a good overview of the large historical trend and in-depth analysis of individual thinkers. Professor Stern's lectures are fantasticerudite but plainspoken, and always engagingand if you like the first few, stay, because theyre consistently good throughout the semester. I especially recommend the course to those unfamiliar with this intellectual tradition, because you learn a lot in an accessible, easygoing manner (workload is light) and get to know some really important, colorful thinkers.
It's a good course, but be prepared to PAY ATTENTION. You can't get notes from slides later on.
